history.content:
Career fairs generally give good chances; asking for referral is probably better as that almost guarantees you an interview.

Apart from that, check out Facebook University, Google Engineering Practicum and Explore Microsoft, three internship programs targetted specifically for freshman.

--

Also startups. They're always recruiting and freshmen are no exception. Angel List (http://angel.co) is a good place to start.

Career fairs generally give good chances; asking for referral is probably better as that almost guarantees you an interview.

Apart from that, check out Facebook University, Google Engineering Practicum and Explore Microsoft, three internship programs targetted specifically for freshman.

children.subject:
Agree to some extent. Ultimately experience matters too - a junior has junior standing (even if they joined CS late or transferred), and a lot of companies actually prefer juniors, mainly because they know they'll be graduating in a year and so can convert them to full-time.

But yes, the skills are I think more pivotal and really what matters in the end.
You can get internships at any level as you can prove you have the skills. A junior with only data structures experience is worse off than a Freshman who has done data structures and discrete math.

history.subject: Getting CS internships as a freshman?
